resources.string: COVID-19 is a respiratory illness caused by a new virus. Symptoms include fever, coughing, a sore throat and shortness of breath. The virus can spread from person to person. Currently there is no treatment for COVID-19. It was first reported in December 2019 in Wuhan City in China. The people most at risk are people 65 or older and people with chronic conditions.

When at home:

◦ Cover your nose and mouth when sneezing and immediately dispose of used tissues. 
◦ Regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces such as; table tops, light switches, door handles, phones, keyboards and toilets. 
◦ Wash your hands regularly and avoid touching your eyes, nose and face with unwashed hands. 

 When outside: 

◦ Wear a cloth mask that covers your nose and mouth when going outside. 
◦ Try to limit unnecessary errands and trips outside. 
◦ Avoid areas that may be crowded such as a public park or shopping centre. 
◦ Keep a 2.5m (6 feet) distance from other people when outside. 
◦ Use sanitiser after touching door handles or other frequently touched objects.

This stage is used to refer to innovations that are currently not being tested in clincal trials. Clinical trials refer to working the the treatment with chemicals to understand reactions or conducting studies on human and non-human test subjects.
This stage refers to finding the most suitable dosage of the treatment through clincal trials of human subject in small groups between 20-80 people.
Phase 2 is when trials are expanded and studies are done to understand their safety and efficacy in the human body with larger groups of people.

Phase 3 asseses the side-effects of the drugs and compares them to standard drugs currently in the market. This phase is used to guage the effectiveness and understand if they are causing any detrimental side-effects.
At this phase, the treatment is approved and licensed by the FDA, however there are ongoing studies being conducted.
This stage means that the drug has been given approval to be made available to the public without having been through all phases of testing.
